text:
SPEAKER: So let's talk a
little bit about gender again.

Because you started your
description of your story

by recounting some of the extra
odds that you had to get over.

I read somewhere that
30% of your scientists
are women, which is incredible.

It should be 50%,
but you'll get there.

Can you talk about how you've
seen that changing in India,

the role of women in science,
in companies, or anywhere else?

KIRAN MAZUMDAR-SHAW:
So, you know,

when I started the
company, I had a sort
of a two pronged objective.

One was, of course,
for scientists

to feel excited about pursuing
a career in India, a research
career in India.

And the second
one was for women.

I wanted women to
be pursuing careers.

And I thought I could provide
them that safe haven for them

to get interested
in pursuing careers.

After 40 years, I
feel I haven't quite
achieved that second objective.

Because although 30% of
my researchers are women,

and I'm seeing more
women get into that fold.

And I'm sure that in
another few years,

you'll get to that
50% level, I still

find that in the rest
of our organization,

I find it very, very difficult
to get women to lead--
SPEAKER: Outside of R&D.

KIRAN MAZUMDAR-SHAW:
--outside of R&D. So like,

for instance, manufacturing,
finance, admin,
those kind of things.

OK, you will get
a few women, but I
want women in leadership roles.
I'm not getting them.

Like, even specialized roles
like regulatory, quality, now

these are roles which you
should find women doing.

And yet, I find it very
difficult to get people.

And, you know,
since you're playing

in a global kind of
arena, you want people
with experience and expertise.

And there are very
few women who actually
fit that kind of a role.

So I would like more
women to play that role.

And yet, I know that in
the past, when I actually

started Biocon, the head
of quality was a woman.

The head of HR that
I had was a woman.

The head of even one part
of my manufacturing I had
was a woman.

So you do have
very strong women.
But they're few and far between.

And therefore, I thought that
when I'm looking for, now,

these high end talent, even
though I order my HR folk

to make sure that they
give preference to women,

there are very, very few
women to choose from.

SPEAKER: It almost
feels like one

has to start earlier in the
value chain, developing talent.

KIRAN MAZUMDAR-SHAW: So that's
something which I'm hoping for.

Because at least,
we've started something

under our corporate
social responsibility.

We have started
the Biocon Academy.
SPEAKER: OK, what's that?

KIRAN MAZUMDAR-SHAW: And
that's like a finishing school.

So I'm taking a lot
of young, raw talent

and shaping them to
be industry ready.

And there, I find that 70%
of the students we picked
are women.

So I'm hoping that they will
change things as we move along.

SPEAKER: And they will go not
just to life science careers?

KIRAN MAZUMDAR-SHAW: This is
largely for life sciences.

So any-- they're being grabbed
by all the life tech companies.
